headline: No Knead Pizza Bianca Recipe
description: Pizza need not have sauce or cheese in order for it to be insanely delicious.
name: No Knead Pizza Bianca Recipe
keywords: pizza, pizza bianca, recipes, The Food Lab, the pizza lab

nutrition.servingSize: makes 1 pizza with about 8 rectangular slices

recipeIngredient: 500 grams (17.5 ounces, about 3 1/4 cups) bread flour
10 grams (.34 ounces, about 2 teaspoons) kosher salt
5 grams (.18 ounces, about 1 1/2 teaspoons) instant or rapid-rise yeast
375 grams (13.25 ounces, 1 cup plus 10.5 tablespoons) lukewarm water
Coarse sea salt such as Maldon or fleur de sel

recipeInstructions.text: Combine flour, salt, and yeast in a large bowl and whisk together until homogenous. Add water and stir with a wooden spoon until no dry flour remains. Cover bowl tightly with plastic wrap and allow to rest at room temperature overnight.

The next day, lightly flour the dough and your hands. Scrape dough out of the bowl onto a well-floured piece of parchment paper set inside a rimmed baking sheet and gently fold dough into an even blob in the center. Dust with flour and cover with a clean kitchen towel. allow to rise at room temperature until nearly doubled in volume, about 2 hours.

30 minutes before baking, adjust oven rack to upper-middle position, place a baking stone on it (or a double stack of rimmed baking sheets) and preheat oven to 550째F (260째C). Gently stretch the dough into an even rectangular shape (you shouldn't have to lift it). Carefully stipple the top surface with your fingertips. Drizzle with olive oil and sprinkle with coarse sea salt and rosemary if using. Transfer entire baking sheet with dough to pizza stone.

Bake for 5 minutes just until the pizza is slightly firm. Remove from oven and transfer pizza to a pizza peel. Discard parchment paper. Return pizza to bake directly on the baking stone until burnished golden brown, about 10 to 15 minutes longer. Remove from oven and allow to cool for 5 minutes. Transfer to a large cutting board, cut into 8 or 12 rectangular slices, and serve.

review.reviewBody:
There are several videos of Antico Forno Pizza Bianca on youtube (including one with Martha Stewart and Jim Lahey) but for a quick look at the baker putting six feet of dough into the oven watch this 2.5 minute one:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MXxySZiPSIs&frags=pl%2Cwn

That's hilarious! My wife and I had our first potato pizza at Forno about twelve years ago. I still remember the ominous statue watching over us. We went home, perfected the technique and have been making potato pizza ever since! (a little added feta goes a long way). That said, you use a photo on your Basic Neapolitan Pizza Dough Recipe however, the photo appears to have more than just a dough. Do you have a recipe for the pizza pictured?

Thanks!

Kenji— cesare Agostini /Rome/ Roscioli makes the pizza Bianca dough with milk initially, beats in mixer; then he adds the water to make a wet dough. What percentage of milk would I use?? I believe for 50 lbs flour he used 32 oz milk but I'm unsure of the milk quantity. Also, why does your recipe omit milk? Thanks!

@gilou

Actually, with long rise times, it doesn't make all that much difference - the yeast multiples and ends up at its largest viable population over the course of the night whether you start with 1% or .2%. I changed the amount for this recipe after realizing that most folks at home don't have a scale that's accurate to 1 gram, but yes - go ahead and use less!

Are you sure you need to use 5g of instant yeast ?
In your no knead bread recipe (http://www.seriouseats.com/basic-no-knead-bread-dough-jim-lahey-recipe), you say 1g for 400g of flour...
Thanks for your amazing site
Gilou
